Class Dollar

java.lang.Object
  Dollar
All Implemented Interfaces:
Money
public class Dollar
extends java.lang.Object
implements Money

An implementation of the Money interface for the US Dollar. Objects of this class are immutable.

Constructor Summary
Dollar()
          Build a zero-valued dollar.
Dollar(Dollar other)
          Build a dollar as a duplicate of the specified dollar.
Dollar(double amount)
          Build a dollar from the given amount.
Dollar(int dollars, int cents)
          Build a dollar from the given dollars and cents.
Dollar(long cents)
          Build a dollar from the given number of cents.

Constructor Detail

Dollar

public Dollar()
Build a zero-valued dollar.

Dollar

public Dollar(int dollars,
              int cents)
Build a dollar from the given dollars and cents. If cents is more than 100, then the number of dollars is increased. i.e. new Dollar(5, 225) is equivalent to new Dollar(7, 25).

Parameters:
dollars - the dollar count
cents - the cents count

Dollar

public Dollar(long cents)
Build a dollar from the given number of cents. The number of dollars is cents/100.

Parameters:
cents - the cents count

Dollar

public Dollar(double amount)
Build a dollar from the given amount. The amount is considered to be a number of dollars with the fractional part as cents. For example, new Dollar(7.25) is equivalent to new Dollar(7, 25).

Dollar

public Dollar(Dollar other)
Build a dollar as a duplicate of the specified dollar.

Parameters:
other - the dollar to duplicate.
Method Detail

asDouble

public double asDouble()
Convert the current money object into a double value.

Specified by:
asDouble in interface Money
Returns:
the double value of this money object.

asLong

public long asLong()
Convert the current money object into a long. Since there is no decimal place in a long integer, the actual result is the same as Math.floor(Money.asDouble() * 100);

Specified by:
asLong in interface Money

isNegative

public boolean isNegative()
Determines if the money object represents a negative quantity.

Specified by:
isNegative in interface Money
Returns:
true if the money object is negative, false otherwise.

Negates the current money object.

div

public double div(Money other)
Divide this mony object by the other money object to produce a dimensionless ratio.For example: 
    Money first, second;
    // ...
    Money result = first.div(second);
is similar to: 
    double first, second;
    // ...
    double result = first / second;

Specified by:
div in interface Money
Parameters:
other - the money object to divide into this one.
Returns:
the ratio of this and other

div

public Money div(double amount)
Divide this money object by a fixed amount to produce a scaled money object. 
    Money money;
    double count;
    // ...
    Money result = money.div(count);
is similar to: 
    double money, count;
    // ...
    double result = money / count;

Specified by:
div in interface Money
Parameters:
amount - the amount to multiply by
Returns:
the product of this and amt

mul

public Money mul(double amount)
Multiply this money object by a fixed amount to produce a scaled money object. It doesn't make sense to multiply two Money objects together, but it does make sense to multiply by a percentage, for example. 
    Money money;
    double percent;
    // ...
    Money result = money.mul(percent);
is similar to: 
    double money, percent;
    // ...
    double result = money * percent;

Specified by:
mul in interface Money
Parameters:
amount - the amount to multiply by
Returns:
the product of this and amt

sub

public Money sub(Money other)
Subtract the other money object from this money object to produce a money object difference. For example: 
    Money first, second;
    // ...
    Money result = first.sub(second);
is similar to: 
    double first, second;
    // ...
    double result = first - second;

Specified by:
sub in interface Money
Parameters:
other - the money object to be subtracted from this one.
Returns:
the difference of this and other

add

public Money add(Money other)
Add the other money object to this money object to produce a money object sum. For example: 
    Money first, second;
    // ...
    Money result = first.add(second);
is similar to: 
    double first, second;
    // ...
    double result = first + second;

Specified by:
add in interface Money
Parameters:
other - the money object to be added to this one.
Returns:
the sum of this and other

equals

public boolean equals(java.lang.Object o)
Overrides Object.equals() to compare as Money.

Parameters:
o - the object against which to compare.
Returns:
true if the two objects are equal by value

compareTo

public int compareTo(Money other)
Compare two money objects. Yields a positive number if this is greater than other, a negative number if this is less than other and zero if they are equal.

Specified by:
compareTo in interface Money
Returns:
-1, 0, or 1 according to the above.

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
The string representation in USD.

Returns:
a string representing the money.
